hypothesis: Early CMA-ES iterations need rough landscape estimate (25% timesteps). Later iterations benefit from more accurate signal (40% timesteps). Variable fidelity may save time while maintaining accuracy.

tuning_runs.notes: FAILED - 25% early timesteps mislead CMA-ES. Score -0.0215 vs baseline, time +7.6 min over budget.
FAILED - 35% early is better than 25% but still worse than fixed 40%. Score -0.0053, time +11.5 min.

result: FAILED - Adaptive timestep switching during CMA-ES is counterproductive
key_finding: CMA-ES covariance adaptation requires consistent fitness landscape. Switching fidelity mid-run disrupts learning and leads to WORSE performance (both time and accuracy) than fixed fidelity.
